title: How to Make an Autumn Bunch

steps.headline: Gather the things you’ll need.
steps.description: Remember that there’s no strict list; you can mix and match what you like. You can gather a variety of differently sized and coloured autumn leaves, or make them all identical. It’s generally best to stick with medium sized to small leaves though, as you want the bunches to be graceful, not oversized and untidy. As for autumn plants, you can take your pick depending on where you live; pine cones, berries or flowers.

steps.headline: Make sure all of your items stick to a colour palette; typically, you’ll be looking for a range of auburn, browns, gold and reds.
steps.description:
Make sure that the ribbon you select adds the ultimate touch – a deep red or gold ribbon, or perhaps a striped or checked one, will be perfect. When gathering your items, remember the following: Your flowers should be removed from sunlight as soon as they are cut so that they will dry with their colours preserved. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Make-an-Autumn-Bunch-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-an-Autumn-Bunch-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Make-an-Autumn-Bunch-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-an-Autumn-Bunch-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Your flowers should also not be fully mature; else they will lose their petals quickly. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Make-an-Autumn-Bunch-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-an-Autumn-Bunch-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Make-an-Autumn-Bunch-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-an-Autumn-Bunch-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}

steps.headline: Dry your flowers.
steps.description: You can use the microwave technique for drying daises or roses, or tie your flowers in small bunches and hang them upside down in a dark, dry area such as an unused closet. Allow your flowers to dry for two to three weeks. Yes, this takes time and patience, but it ensures that your bunch lasts longer and makes it look all the more attractive.

steps.headline: Dry your autumn leaves.
Dust your leaves with glitter to enhance their beauty.
steps.description: Shades of gold, silver or white are all great colours to add. This is optional.

steps.headline: Arrange your bunch.
steps.description: The hardest part - waiting – is over, and your bunches will be complete in minutes. Gather up your flowers and leaves and work on arranging them how you would like. Keep in mind the colours and sizes and what kind of look you’re trying to achieve – graceful, pretty, bright? Be gentle and carefully with your plants.

steps.headline: Tie them with ribbon.
steps.description: Once your bunch is perfect, carefully tie it with your ribbon. To secure the bunch, you may want to tie it with thin but strong string first, because the silkiness of the ribbon may not hold the bunch together as well. Then tie the ribbon around it for decoration. You can simply tie it and let the two sides of ribbon dangle, or tie it in a bow. You could also thread small charms or beads along your ribbon, which work especially well if you’re going to hang the bunch up.

steps.headline: Let the bunch dry, if you like.
steps.description: You can keep the bunch in a cool, dark and dry area for a week or so to ensure it is preserved and dried properly.

steps.headline: Enjoy!
steps.description: You can make several bunches, drying flowers at different periods, and then use them to decorate your house for a special occasion. Or you can hang these bunches from your window, or car mirror, or add them to a gift or basket for that final autumnal touch.
